texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I'M ALL DONE:  I'm not working on Linux compatibility for the XPS 13 any longer. I've purchased a Lenovo X1 Carbon (3rd gen) and that's my preferred laptop. More on this change later.
texts.text: I'M ALL DONE:  I'm not working on Linux compatibility for the XPS 13 any longer. I've purchased a Lenovo X1 Carbon (3rd gen) and that's my preferred laptop. More on this change later.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've been looking for a good laptop to run Linux for a while now and my new Dell XPS 13 9343 has arrived. It was released at CES in 2015 and it received quite a lot of attention for packing a large amount of pixels into a very small laptop frame with excellent battery life. Ars Technica has a  great overall review  of the device.
texts.text: I've been looking for a good laptop to run Linux for a while now and my new Dell XPS 13 9343 has arrived. It was released at CES in 2015 and it received quite a lot of attention for packing a large amount of pixels into a very small laptop frame with excellent battery life. Ars Technica has a  great overall review  of the device.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Linux support has been historically good on the previous generation XPS 13's and a  blog post from Dell  suggests that the latest revision will have good support as well. For a deep dive on the hardware inside the laptop, review  this GitHub Gist .
texts.text: Linux support has been historically good on the previous generation XPS 13's and a  blog post from Dell  suggests that the latest revision will have good support as well. For a deep dive on the hardware inside the laptop, review  this GitHub Gist .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After wiping Windows 8.1 off the laptop, I started with the Fedora 21 installation. If you want to run Linux on one of these laptops, here's what you need to know:
texts.text: After wiping Windows 8.1 off the laptop, I started with the Fedora 21 installation. If you want to run Linux on one of these laptops, here's what you need to know:

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: The good
texts.text: The good

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: All of the most basic devices work just fine. The display, storage, and peripheral connections (USB, SD card slot, mini DisplayPort) all work out of the box in Linux 3.18.5 with Fedora 21. The display looks great with GNOME 3's default HiDPI settings and it's very readable with the default font sizes without HiDPI (although this is a bit subjective).
texts.text: All of the most basic devices work just fine. The display, storage, and peripheral connections (USB, SD card slot, mini DisplayPort) all work out of the box in Linux 3.18.5 with Fedora 21. The display looks great with GNOME 3's default HiDPI settings and it's very readable with the default font sizes without HiDPI (although this is a bit subjective).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The webcam works without any additional configuration the video quality is excellent.
texts.text: The webcam works without any additional configuration the video quality is excellent.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The wireless card in the laptop I received is a BCM4352:
texts.text: The wireless card in the laptop I received is a BCM4352:

texts.label: code
texts.orig: 02:00.0 Network controller: Broadcom Corporation BCM4352 802.11ac Wireless Network Adapter (rev 03)
texts.text: 02:00.0 Network controller: Broadcom Corporation BCM4352 802.11ac Wireless Network Adapter (rev 03)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: It's possible to get this card working with the b43 kernel modules but I've had better luck with the binary blob STA drivers from Broadcom. There are  plenty of guides  out there to help you install the kernel module for your Fedora kernel. I've had great network performance with the binary driver.
texts.text: It's possible to get this card working with the b43 kernel modules but I've had better luck with the binary blob STA drivers from Broadcom. There are  plenty of guides  out there to help you install the kernel module for your Fedora kernel. I've had great network performance with the binary driver.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Some users are seeing Intel wireless cards in their Dell XPS 13's, especially in Europe. Opening the laptop for service  isn't terribly difficult  and you could replace the bluetooth/wireless card with a different one.
texts.text: Some users are seeing Intel wireless cards in their Dell XPS 13's, especially in Europe. Opening the laptop for service  isn't terribly difficult  and you could replace the bluetooth/wireless card with a different one.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: PRO TIP:  If you're seeing errors in your journald logs about NetworkManager being unable to scan for access points, be sure to hit the wireless switch key on your keyboard (Fn-F12) to enable the card. This had me stumped for about 45 minutes. There's an option in the BIOS to disable the switch and let the OS control the wireless card.
texts.text: PRO TIP:  If you're seeing errors in your journald logs about NetworkManager being unable to scan for access points, be sure to hit the wireless switch key on your keyboard (Fn-F12) to enable the card. This had me stumped for about 45 minutes. There's an option in the BIOS to disable the switch and let the OS control the wireless card.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The special keyboard buttons (volume up/down, brightness up/down) all work flawlessly.
texts.text: The special keyboard buttons (volume up/down, brightness up/down) all work flawlessly.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: The bad
texts.text: The bad

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The touchpad and keyboard are on the I2C bus and this creates some problems. Many users have reported that keys on the keyboard seem to repeat themselves while you're typing and the touchpad has an issue where X stops receiving input from it. However, when the touchpad seems to freeze, the kernel still sees data coming from the device (verified with evtest and evemu-record).
texts.text: The touchpad and keyboard are on the I2C bus and this creates some problems. Many users have reported that keys on the keyboard seem to repeat themselves while you're typing and the touchpad has an issue where X stops receiving input from it. However, when the touchpad seems to freeze, the kernel still sees data coming from the device (verified with evtest and evemu-record).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There are some open bugs and discussion about the touchpad issues:
texts.text: There are some open bugs and discussion about the touchpad issues:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Linux Support is Terrible on the New Dell XPS 13 (2015)'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Linux Support is Terrible on the New Dell XPS 13 (2015)'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig:
[<RawText children=('touchpad does not respond to tap-to-clicks in I2C mode in Ubuntu 15.04 on '
 '2015 XPS 13 (9343)')>]
texts.text:
[<RawText children=('touchpad does not respond to tap-to-clicks in I2C mode in Ubuntu 15.04 on '
 '2015 XPS 13 (9343)')>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Dell XPS 13 9343 (2015) touchpad freeze'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Dell XPS 13 9343 (2015) touchpad freeze'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can connect up a mouse and keyboard to the laptop and work around those issues. However, dragging around some big peripherals with such a small laptop isn't a great long-term solution. Some users suggested blacklisting the i2c_hid module so that the touchpad shows up as a plain PS/2 touchpad but I'm still seeing freezes even after making that change.
texts.text: You can connect up a mouse and keyboard to the laptop and work around those issues. However, dragging around some big peripherals with such a small laptop isn't a great long-term solution. Some users suggested blacklisting the i2c_hid module so that the touchpad shows up as a plain PS/2 touchpad but I'm still seeing freezes even after making that change.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you're having one of those “touchpad on the I2C bus?” moments like I had, read Synaptics'  brief page about Intertouch . Using the I2C bus saves power, reduces USB port consumption, and allows for more powerful multi-touch gestures.
texts.text: If you're having one of those “touchpad on the I2C bus?” moments like I had, read Synaptics'  brief page about Intertouch . Using the I2C bus saves power, reduces USB port consumption, and allows for more powerful multi-touch gestures.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Oddly enough, the touchscreen is an ELAN Touchscreen and it runs over USB. It suffers from the same freezes that the touchpad does.
texts.text: Oddly enough, the touchscreen is an ELAN Touchscreen and it runs over USB. It suffers from the same freezes that the touchpad does.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: The ugly
texts.text: The ugly

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sound is a big problem. The microphone, speakers and headphone port don't work under 3.18.5 and 3.19.0-rc7. The audio device is a ALC3263 from RealTek and it should use the same module as the RT286. However, the probing still fails and the module can't be used. The  module code  seems to be correct but the probing still fails.
texts.text: Sound is a big problem. The microphone, speakers and headphone port don't work under 3.18.5 and 3.19.0-rc7. The audio device is a ALC3263 from RealTek and it should use the same module as the RT286. However, the probing still fails and the module can't be used. The  module code  seems to be correct but the probing still fails.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's an open bug on Launchpad about the problem:
texts.text: There's an open bug on Launchpad about the problem:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='Audio broken on 2015 XPS 13 (9343) in I2S mode in Ubuntu 14.10/15.04'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='Audio broken on 2015 XPS 13 (9343) in I2S mode in Ubuntu 14.10/15.04'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='No sound on Dell XPS 13 9343 (2015 model)'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='No sound on Dell XPS 13 9343 (2015 model)'>]

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: [<RawText children='broadwell-audio: rt286 device appears, no sound (Dell XPS 13 9343)'>]
texts.text: [<RawText children='broadwell-audio: rt286 device appears, no sound (Dell XPS 13 9343)'>]

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I connected up an old Syba USB audio device to the USB port and was able to get sound immediately. This is also a horrible workaround.
texts.text: I connected up an old Syba USB audio device to the USB port and was able to get sound immediately. This is also a horrible workaround.

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: What now?
texts.text: What now?

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: From what I gather, Dell is extremely eager to make Linux work on the new XPS 13 and we should see some movement on these bugs soon. I'm still doing a bunch of testing on my own with kernel 3.19 and I'll be keeping this page updated as news becomes available.
texts.text: From what I gather, Dell is extremely eager to make Linux work on the new XPS 13 and we should see some movement on these bugs soon. I'm still doing a bunch of testing on my own with kernel 3.19 and I'll be keeping this page updated as news becomes available.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If you know much about the I2C bus or about the sound devices in this laptop and you have some time available to help, just let me know where to send the beer. ;)
texts.text: If you know much about the I2C bus or about the sound devices in this laptop and you have some time available to help, just let me know where to send the beer. ;)

texts.label: section_header
texts.orig: Latest updates
texts.text: Latest updates

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Added Red Hat bug link for sound issues.
texts.text: Added Red Hat bug link for sound issues.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The touchpad bug has been reduced to a kernel issue. Recordings from evemu-record look fine when they're played back in X. Users reported in Launchpad and in the Red Hat bug that kernel 3.16 works perfectly but 3.17 doesn't. A kernel bisection will most likely be required to find the patch that broke the touchpad.
texts.text: The touchpad bug has been reduced to a kernel issue. Recordings from evemu-record look fine when they're played back in X. Users reported in Launchpad and in the Red Hat bug that kernel 3.16 works perfectly but 3.17 doesn't. A kernel bisection will most likely be required to find the patch that broke the touchpad.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Many users find that adding
texts.text: Many users find that adding

texts.label: code
texts.orig: acpi.os="!Windows 2013"
texts.text: acpi.os="!Windows 2013"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to the kernel boot line will bring the audio card online after 1-3 reboots. Apparently there is some level of state information stored in memory that requires a few reboots to clear it. I haven't verified this yet.
texts.text: to the kernel boot line will bring the audio card online after 1-3 reboots. Apparently there is some level of state information stored in memory that requires a few reboots to clear it. I haven't verified this yet.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Kernel bisect for the touchpad issue is underway. Every 3.16.x kernel I built would keep the trackpad in PS/2 mode and that's not helpful at all. There's no multi-finger taps/clicks/gestures. 3.17.0 works perfectly, however. My gut says something broke down between 3.17.0 and 3.18.0 but it might actually be closer to 3.17.4 since Fedora 21's initial kernel is 3.17.4 (and the touchpad doesn't work well with it).
texts.text: Kernel bisect for the touchpad issue is underway. Every 3.16.x kernel I built would keep the trackpad in PS/2 mode and that's not helpful at all. There's no multi-finger taps/clicks/gestures. 3.17.0 works perfectly, however. My gut says something broke down between 3.17.0 and 3.18.0 but it might actually be closer to 3.17.4 since Fedora 21's initial kernel is 3.17.4 (and the touchpad doesn't work well with it).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A post was made on  Barton's Blog  yesterday about Dell being aware of the Linux issues.  (Thanks to Chris' comment below!)
texts.text: A post was made on  Barton's Blog  yesterday about Dell being aware of the Linux issues.  (Thanks to Chris' comment below!)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After about 35 kernel builds during the most frustrating git bisect of my life, I found the  problematic patch . The  Red Hat bug  is updated now and I'm hoping that someone with a detailed knowledge of this part of the kernel can make sense of it:
texts.text: After about 35 kernel builds during the most frustrating git bisect of my life, I found the  problematic patch . The  Red Hat bug  is updated now and I'm hoping that someone with a detailed knowledge of this part of the kernel can make sense of it:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
From d1c7e29e8d276c669e8790bb8be9f505ddc48888 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Gwendal Grignou <gwendal@chromium.org>
Date: Thu, 11 Dec 2014 16:02:45 -0800
Subject: HID: i2c-hid: prevent buffer overflow in early IRQ

Before ->start() is called, bufsize size is set to HID_MIN_BUFFER_SIZE,
64 bytes. While processing the IRQ, we were asking to receive up to
wMaxInputLength bytes, which can be bigger than 64 bytes.

Later, when ->start is run, a proper bufsize will be calculated.

Given wMaxInputLength is said to be unreliable in other part of the
code, set to receive only what we can even if it results in truncated
reports.

Signed-off-by: Gwendal Grignou <gwendal@chromium.org>
Reviewed-by: Benjamin Tissoires <benjamin.tissoires@redhat.com>
Cc: stable@vger.kernel.org
Signed-off-by: Jiri Kosina <jkosina@suse.cz>

diff --git a/drivers/hid/i2c-hid/i2c-hid.c b/drivers/hid/i2c-hid/i2c-hid.c
index 747d544..9c014803b4 100644
--- a/drivers/hid/i2c-hid/i2c-hid.c
+++ b/drivers/hid/i2c-hid/i2c-hid.c
@@ -369,7 +369,7 @@ static int i2c_hid_hwreset(struct i2c_client *client)
 static void i2c_hid_get_input(struct i2c_hid *ihid)
 {
 	int ret, ret_size;
-	int size = le16_to_cpu(ihid->hdesc.wMaxInputLength);
+	int size = ihid->bufsize;

 	ret = i2c_master_recv(ihid->client, ihid->inbuf, size);
 	if (ret != size) {
texts.text:
From d1c7e29e8d276c669e8790bb8be9f505ddc48888 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Gwendal Grignou <gwendal@chromium.org>
Date: Thu, 11 Dec 2014 16:02:45 -0800
Subject: HID: i2c-hid: prevent buffer overflow in early IRQ

Before ->start() is called, bufsize size is set to HID_MIN_BUFFER_SIZE,
64 bytes. While processing the IRQ, we were asking to receive up to
wMaxInputLength bytes, which can be bigger than 64 bytes.

Later, when ->start is run, a proper bufsize will be calculated.

Given wMaxInputLength is said to be unreliable in other part of the
code, set to receive only what we can even if it results in truncated
reports.

Signed-off-by: Gwendal Grignou <gwendal@chromium.org>
Reviewed-by: Benjamin Tissoires <benjamin.tissoires@redhat.com>
Cc: stable@vger.kernel.org
Signed-off-by: Jiri Kosina <jkosina@suse.cz>

diff --git a/drivers/hid/i2c-hid/i2c-hid.c b/drivers/hid/i2c-hid/i2c-hid.c
index 747d544..9c014803b4 100644
--- a/drivers/hid/i2c-hid/i2c-hid.c
+++ b/drivers/hid/i2c-hid/i2c-hid.c
@@ -369,7 +369,7 @@ static int i2c_hid_hwreset(struct i2c_client *client)
 static void i2c_hid_get_input(struct i2c_hid *ihid)
 {
 	int ret, ret_size;
-	int size = le16_to_cpu(ihid->hdesc.wMaxInputLength);
+	int size = ihid->bufsize;

 	ret = i2c_master_recv(ihid->client, ihid->inbuf, size);
 	if (ret != size) {

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I reverted the patch in Linux 3.19-rc7 and built the kernel. The touchpad works flawlessly. However, simply reverting the patch probably isn't the best idea long term. ;)
texts.text: I reverted the patch in Linux 3.19-rc7 and built the kernel. The touchpad works flawlessly. However, simply reverting the patch probably isn't the best idea long term. ;)

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: The  audio patch  mentioned in the  Launchpad bug report  didn't work for me on Linux 3.19-rc7.
texts.text: The  audio patch  mentioned in the  Launchpad bug report  didn't work for me on Linux 3.19-rc7.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Progress is still being made on the touchpad in the  Red Hat bug  ticket. If you can live with the pad working as PS/2, you can get sound by adding
texts.text: Progress is still being made on the touchpad in the  Red Hat bug  ticket. If you can live with the pad working as PS/2, you can get sound by adding

texts.label: code
texts.orig: acpi_osi="!Windows 2013"
texts.text: acpi_osi="!Windows 2013"

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: to your kernel command line. Once you do that, you'll need to:
texts.text: to your kernel command line. Once you do that, you'll need to:

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Do a warm reboot
texts.text: Do a warm reboot

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Wait for the OS to boot, then do a full poweroff
texts.text: Wait for the OS to boot, then do a full poweroff

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Boot the laptop, then do a full poweroff
texts.text: Boot the laptop, then do a full poweroff

texts.label: list_item
texts.orig: Sound should now be working
texts.text: Sound should now be working

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: If sound still isn't working, you may need to install
texts.text: If sound still isn't working, you may need to install

texts.label: code
texts.orig: pavucontrol
texts.text: pavucontrol

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , the PulseAudio volume controller, and disable the HDMI sound output that is built into the Broadwell chip.
texts.text: , the PulseAudio volume controller, and disable the HDMI sound output that is built into the Broadwell chip.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: This obviously isn't a long-term solution, but it's a fair workaround.
texts.text: This obviously isn't a long-term solution, but it's a fair workaround.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There is now a  patch  that you can apply to 3.18 or 3.19 kernels that eliminates the trackpad freeze:
texts.text: There is now a  patch  that you can apply to 3.18 or 3.19 kernels that eliminates the trackpad freeze:

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
From 2a2aa272447d0ad4340c73db91bd8e995f6a0c3f Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Benjamin Tissoires <benjamin.tissoires@redhat.com>
Date: Tue, 10 Feb 2015 12:40:13 -0500
Subject: [PATCH] HID: multitouch: force release of touches when i2c
 communication is not reliable

The Dell XPS 13 9343 (2015) shows that from time to time, i2c_hid misses
some reports from the touchpad. This can lead to a freeze of the cursor
in user space when the missing report contains a touch release information.

Win 8 devices should have a contact count reliable, to we can safely
release all touches that has not been seen in the current report.

Signed-off-by: Benjamin Tissoires <benjamin.tissoires@redhat.com>
---
 drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c | 8 ++++++++
 1 file changed, 8 insertions(+)

diff --git a/drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c b/drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c
index f65e78b..48b051e 100644
--- a/drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c
+++ b/drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c
@@ -1021,6 +1021,14 @@ static int mt_probe(struct hid_device *hdev, const struct hid_device_id *id)
 	if (id->vendor == HID_ANY_ID && id->product == HID_ANY_ID)
 		td->serial_maybe = true;

+	if ((id->group == HID_GROUP_MULTITOUCH_WIN_8) && (hdev->bus == BUS_I2C))
+		/*
+		 * Some i2c sensors are not completely reliable with the i2c
+		 * communication. Force release of unseen touches in a report
+		 * to prevent bad behavior from user space.
+		 */
+		td->mtclass.quirks |= MT_QUIRK_NOT_SEEN_MEANS_UP;
+
 	ret = hid_parse(hdev);
 	if (ret != 0)
 		return ret;
texts.text:
From 2a2aa272447d0ad4340c73db91bd8e995f6a0c3f Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Benjamin Tissoires <benjamin.tissoires@redhat.com>
Date: Tue, 10 Feb 2015 12:40:13 -0500
Subject: [PATCH] HID: multitouch: force release of touches when i2c
 communication is not reliable

The Dell XPS 13 9343 (2015) shows that from time to time, i2c_hid misses
some reports from the touchpad. This can lead to a freeze of the cursor
in user space when the missing report contains a touch release information.

Win 8 devices should have a contact count reliable, to we can safely
release all touches that has not been seen in the current report.

Signed-off-by: Benjamin Tissoires <benjamin.tissoires@redhat.com>
---
 drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c | 8 ++++++++
 1 file changed, 8 insertions(+)

diff --git a/drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c b/drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c
index f65e78b..48b051e 100644
--- a/drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c
+++ b/drivers/hid/hid-multitouch.c
@@ -1021,6 +1021,14 @@ static int mt_probe(struct hid_device *hdev, const struct hid_device_id *id)
 	if (id->vendor == HID_ANY_ID && id->product == HID_ANY_ID)
 		td->serial_maybe = true;

+	if ((id->group == HID_GROUP_MULTITOUCH_WIN_8) && (hdev->bus == BUS_I2C))
+		/*
+		 * Some i2c sensors are not completely reliable with the i2c
+		 * communication. Force release of unseen touches in a report
+		 * to prevent bad behavior from user space.
+		 */
+		td->mtclass.quirks |= MT_QUIRK_NOT_SEEN_MEANS_UP;
+
 	ret = hid_parse(hdev);
 	if (ret != 0)
 		return ret;

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I've tested it against 3.19-rc7 as well as Fedora's 3.18.5. However, tapping still doesn't work yet with more than one finger. The touchpad jumps around a bit when you apply two fingers to it.
texts.text: I've tested it against 3.19-rc7 as well as Fedora's 3.18.5. However, tapping still doesn't work yet with more than one finger. The touchpad jumps around a bit when you apply two fingers to it.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Rene commented below that he  found a post in alsa devel with a patch  for the “Dell Dino” that looks like it might help with the i2c audio issues. Another kernel maintainer replied and asked for some of the code to be rewritten to make it easier to handle audio quirks. UPDATE: Audio patch didn't work.
texts.text: Rene commented below that he  found a post in alsa devel with a patch  for the “Dell Dino” that looks like it might help with the i2c audio issues. Another kernel maintainer replied and asked for some of the code to be rewritten to make it easier to handle audio quirks. UPDATE: Audio patch didn't work.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: We've created an IRC channel on Freenode: #xps13.
texts.text: We've created an IRC channel on Freenode: #xps13.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's an interesting  kernel patch mentioning “Dell Dino”  that is line for inclusion in 3.20-rc1. Someone in IRC found “Dell Dino” mentioned on a  Dell business purchase page . The board name from dmidecode in the patch is  0144P8  but that doesn't match other known board names. My i5-5200U with touch is  0TM99H  while a user with a non-touch i5 has a board name of  OTRX4F . Other i5 touch models have the same board name as mine. All BIOS revisions found so far are A00 (the latest on Dell's site).
texts.text: There's an interesting  kernel patch mentioning “Dell Dino”  that is line for inclusion in 3.20-rc1. Someone in IRC found “Dell Dino” mentioned on a  Dell business purchase page . The board name from dmidecode in the patch is  0144P8  but that doesn't match other known board names. My i5-5200U with touch is  0TM99H  while a user with a non-touch i5 has a board name of  OTRX4F . Other i5 touch models have the same board name as mine. All BIOS revisions found so far are A00 (the latest on Dell's site).

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: A probe for the rt286 module looks like it starts to happen and then it fails (skip to line 795):
texts.text: A probe for the rt286 module looks like it starts to happen and then it fails (skip to line 795):

texts.label: code
texts.orig:
[    4.141189] rt286 i2c-INT343A:00: probe

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I received an email from a Realtek developer about the sound card in the XPS:
texts.text: I received an email from a Realtek developer about the sound card in the XPS:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I see “rt286 i2c-INT343A:00: Device with ID register 0 is not rt286” in the log. It means there are something wrong when the driver is trying to read the device id of codec. I believe that is due to I2C read/write issue. ALC3263 is a dual mode (I2S and HDA) codec. And BIOS will decide which mode according to OS type. So, if you want to use i2s mode, you need to configure your BIOS to set ALC3263 to I2S mode.
texts.text: I see “rt286 i2c-INT343A:00: Device with ID register 0 is not rt286” in the log. It means there are something wrong when the driver is trying to read the device id of codec. I believe that is due to I2C read/write issue. ALC3263 is a dual mode (I2S and HDA) codec. And BIOS will decide which mode according to OS type. So, if you want to use i2s mode, you need to configure your BIOS to set ALC3263 to I2S mode.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After poring through the  DSDT and other ACPI tables  over the weekend (and building way too many kernels with overriden DSDT's), it sounds like a BIOS update may be required for the sound card to function properly. The  sound devices  specified in the DSDT that are on the i2c bus are only activated after a BUNCH of checks succeed. One of them is the check of
texts.text: After poring through the  DSDT and other ACPI tables  over the weekend (and building way too many kernels with overriden DSDT's), it sounds like a BIOS update may be required for the sound card to function properly. The  sound devices  specified in the DSDT that are on the i2c bus are only activated after a BUNCH of checks succeed. One of them is the check of

texts.label: code
texts.orig: OSYS
texts.text: OSYS

texts.text: , the system's operating system. Setting

texts.text: acpi_osi="Windows 2013"

texts.text: does flip

texts.text: 0x07DD

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: , but that's only part of the fix. There are other variables checked, like
texts.text: , but that's only part of the fix. There are other variables checked, like

texts.label: code
texts.orig: CODS
texts.text: CODS

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: (that shows up very often) that are instantiated early in the DSDT but I can't find them ever being set to a value anywhere in the DSDT code. These variables equal zero by default and that disables critical parts of the sound device.
texts.text: (that shows up very often) that are instantiated early in the DSDT but I can't find them ever being set to a value anywhere in the DSDT code. These variables equal zero by default and that disables critical parts of the sound device.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: My take: This laptop is going to need a BIOS update of some sort before we can get sound working properly in Linux with an i2c touchpad. If someone is more skilled with DSDT's than I am, I'll be glad to share all of my work that I've tried so far. As for now, I'm going to be waiting eagerly for some type of firmware update from Dell.
texts.text: My take: This laptop is going to need a BIOS update of some sort before we can get sound working properly in Linux with an i2c touchpad. If someone is more skilled with DSDT's than I am, I'll be glad to share all of my work that I've tried so far. As for now, I'm going to be waiting eagerly for some type of firmware update from Dell.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's some progress on the sound card in Linux! After building the latest commits from  linux.git's master branch , my XPS started showing a device called “broadwell-rt286” in pavucontrol. It showed up as a normal audio device but it had no output support, only input. I tried to enable the microphone but I couldn't record any sound.
texts.text: There's some progress on the sound card in Linux! After building the latest commits from  linux.git's master branch , my XPS started showing a device called “broadwell-rt286” in pavucontrol. It showed up as a normal audio device but it had no output support, only input. I tried to enable the microphone but I couldn't record any sound.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I found a  kernel bug  from a ThinkPad Helix 2 user with a very similar hardware setup. Their rt286 device is on the I2S bus with a Haswell SoC. Their fix was to copy over the latest firmware binaries from  linux-firmware.git  and reboot. I did the same and an output device suddenly showed up in pavucontrol after a reboot.
texts.text: I found a  kernel bug  from a ThinkPad Helix 2 user with a very similar hardware setup. Their rt286 device is on the I2S bus with a Haswell SoC. Their fix was to copy over the latest firmware binaries from  linux-firmware.git  and reboot. I did the same and an output device suddenly showed up in pavucontrol after a reboot.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: When I played sounds via aplay, canberra-gtk-play, and rhythmbox, I could see the signal level fluctuating in pavucontrol on the broadwell-rt286 device. However, I couldn't hear the sound through the speakers. I connected headphones and I couldn't hear any sound there either.
texts.text: When I played sounds via aplay, canberra-gtk-play, and rhythmbox, I could see the signal level fluctuating in pavucontrol on the broadwell-rt286 device. However, I couldn't hear the sound through the speakers. I connected headphones and I couldn't hear any sound there either.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: There's now a  kernel bug ticket  open for the sound issue.
texts.text: There's now a  kernel bug ticket  open for the sound issue.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Stay tuned for a BIOS update with a potential keyboard repeat fix. It's already been talked about in IRC as a potential A01 release sssssssssssoon:
texts.text: Stay tuned for a BIOS update with a potential keyboard repeat fix. It's already been talked about in IRC as a potential A01 release sssssssssssoon:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: someone asked about the fix for the repeating keypresses. yes, it was traced back to the source and will be fixed on all affected Dell platforms soon
texts.text: someone asked about the fix for the repeating keypresses. yes, it was traced back to the source and will be fixed on all affected Dell platforms soon

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: I just saw that the one for 9343 was promoted to our factories so should be up on support.dell.com any day now as BIOS A01
texts.text: I just saw that the one for 9343 was promoted to our factories so should be up on support.dell.com any day now as BIOS A01

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: You can get notifications about driver releases for the XPS on  Dell's site .
texts.text: You can get notifications about driver releases for the XPS on  Dell's site .

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Sound on the I2S bus is working in Linux 4.0-rc2!   See note from 2015-03-08 below.  I was too exhausted last night for a full write-up, but here's the gist of what I did:
texts.text: Sound on the I2S bus is working in Linux 4.0-rc2!   See note from 2015-03-08 below.  I was too exhausted last night for a full write-up, but here's the gist of what I did:

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: First off, build 4.0-rc2 with all of the available I2C and ALSA SoC modules. I haven't narrowed down which modules are critical quite yet. Once you've built the kernel and rebooted into it, run
texts.text: First off, build 4.0-rc2 with all of the available I2C and ALSA SoC modules. I haven't narrowed down which modules are critical quite yet. Once you've built the kernel and rebooted into it, run

texts.label: code
texts.orig: alsamixer
texts.text: alsamixer

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: and choose the
texts.text: and choose the

texts.label: code
texts.orig: broadwell-rt286
texts.text: broadwell-rt286

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: card. Hold the right arrow key until you go all the way to the right of the alsamixer display and press M to unmute the last control there. You should now be able to turn up the volume and play some test sounds.
texts.text: card. Hold the right arrow key until you go all the way to the right of the alsamixer display and press M to unmute the last control there. You should now be able to turn up the volume and play some test sounds.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Luckily, no update for linux-firmware is required. Also, there's no need for any ALSA UCM files as I had originally thought.
texts.text: Luckily, no update for linux-firmware is required. Also, there's no need for any ALSA UCM files as I had originally thought.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: Stay tuned for a more in-depth write-up soon.
texts.text: Stay tuned for a more in-depth write-up soon.

texts.label: paragraph
texts.orig: After a few more reboots, I can't get sound working again. I'm wondering if I had an errant
texts.text: After a few more reboots, I can't get sound working again. I'm wondering if I had an errant

texts.label: code
texts.orig: acpi_osi
texts.text: acpi_osi
